options.c: To fight against the Irish King

options.c: The United States dropped atomic bombs on Japan

134.note: Britain and France developed the world's only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde.

options.a: The authority of the monarch over Parliament
options.b: The authority of the Pope in Scotland
options.c: The three separate Estates of Scottish parliament

136.note: The Castle is a dominant feature of the skyline in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has a long history, dating back to the early Middle Ages.

137.question: At the General Election in May 2010, what happened for the first time since February 1974?

options.a: Only two parties got any votes
options.b: No political party won an overall majority
options.c: The Labour Party got no votes
options.d: The Liberal Democrats won an overall majority

138.note: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.

139.question: In 1688 William of Orange invaded England with little resistance and then ruled peacefully with his wife Mary. This was later called:
139.note: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. 140.question: Which of these statements about the evacuation of Dunkirk is false?

options.c: The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'
options.d: Many British civilians aided the naval evacuation in their own boats

141.question: During Edward VI's reign, what book was written to be used in the Church of England that is still used today?
141.note: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.

142.question: Bonnie Prince Charlie's army were finally defeated by George II's army at which 1746 Battle?
142.note: Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746. Charles escaped back to Europe.

143.note: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

144.note: In 1969, Monty Python's Flying Circus introduced a new type of progressive comedy. Stand-up comedy, where a solo comedian talks to a live audience, has become popular again in recent years.

145.question: Why was Mary Queen of Scots executed?

options.a: She was suspected of plotting against Elizabeth I
options.b: She was suspected of involvement in her husband's murder
options.c: She made Roman Catholic services illegal
options.d: She handed the throne to her Protestant son, Edward VI

146.note: Civil war between the king and Parliament began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

147.question: Many Huguenot immigrants came to England between 1680 and 1720. Who were they?
147.note: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

148.question: Where does Nelson's column, the monument to Admiral Nelson, stand?

options.c: Portsmouth near his ship HMS Victory
options.d: Plymouth near his ship HMS Victory

149.question: Which of these statements about The Proms is false?

options.b: It is organised by the BBC
options.d: It takes place in various venues

150.question: What was the purpose of the Statute of Rhuddlan?

options.a: It annexed Wales to the Crown of England

options.c: It annexed Scotland to the Crown of England
options.d: It gave Scotland to Robert the Bruce

151.question: Which English King fought at the Battle of Agincourt in 1415?
151.note: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

152.question: Which one of these was not an Allied Power?
152.note: Britain was part of the Allied Powers, which included (amongst others) France, Russia, Japan, Belgium, Serbia - and later, Greece, Italy, Romania and the United States.

153.question: Where did the Boer War against settlers from the Netherlands take place?
153.note: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902: The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers.

154.question: Who introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan?
154.note: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

155.question: What was the name of the British sailor who was the fastest person to sail round the world single-handed?
155.note: Dame Ellen MacArthur is a yachtswoman and in 2004 became the fastest person to sail around the world singlehanded.

156.question: Who succeeded Edward VI as monarch of England?
156.note: Edward died at the age of 15 after ruling for just over six years, and his half-sister Mary became queen.

157.question: Which classical composer born in 1659 was the organist at Westminster Abbey?
157.note: Henry Purcell (1659-95) was the organist at Westminster Abbey.

158.question: For what has Sir Steven Redgrave won Olympic medals?
158.note: Sir Steve Redgrave (1962-) won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games and is one of Britain's greatest Olympians.

159.question: What as the biggest source of employment in Britain before the Industrial Revolution?
159.note: Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain.

160.question: Who became Prime Minister in 1945?
160.note: In 1945 the British people elected a Labour government. The new Prime Minister was Clement Attlee, who promised to introduce the welfare state outlined in the Beveridge Report.

161.question: What was the Magna Carta?

options.a: A map showing the countries of England
options.b: A map showing the borders of England
options.c: A charter of rights that King John was forced to agree to by his noblemen
options.d: A charter of rights that King John forced his noblemen to agree to

162.question: On what date did the First World War end?
162.note: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

163.question: What was the population of the UK in the year 1600?
163.note: The population of the UK was just over 4 million in 1600.

164.question: What year was the Turner prize established?
164.note: The Turner Prize was established in 1984 and celebrates contemporary art.

165.question: When was the National Health Service established?
165.note: In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use.

166.question: In what year did Henry VIII take the throne?
166.note: Henry VIII was king of England from 21 April 1509 until his death on 28 January 1547

167.question: How long ago did Britain become separated from the Continent by the Channel
167.note: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.

168.question: In Ireland, what event caused a million deaths and the emigration of one and a half million people to the United States and England in the 19th century?

options.a: Famine caused by the failure of the potato crop
options.c: War with England over Home Rule

169.question: Where was the Great Exhibition of 1851 held?
169.note: In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park in the Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass.

170.question: Canterbury Cathedral was built in what period?
170.note: The Middle Ages saw the development of a national culture and identity. Canterbury Cathedral was built in the Middle Ages.

171.question: What was the name of the railway that Isambard Kingdom Brunel was responsible for constructing?
171.note: Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway, which was the first major railway built in Britain.

172.question: What is the 18th century period of many new ideas on politics, philosophy and science called?
172.note: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'.

173.question: What was the name of the tribe led by Boudicca?
173.note: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

174.question: In which battle did the Scottish defeat the English in 1314
174.note: In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

175.question: The Domesday Book recorded details of:

options.a: The making of the Bayeux Tapestry
options.c: All the towns, villages, people and animals in England

175.note: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book.

176.question: Where was William Shakespeare born?
176.note: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

177.question: After Charles I's execution by Parliament in 1649, who did the Scots declare King?

options.c: Charles I's son, also called Charles

177.note: The Scots had not agreed to the execution of Charles I and declared his son Charles II to be king.

178.question: Who developed the television?
178.note: The television was developed by Scotsman John Logie Baird (1888-1946) in the 1920s.

179.question: In the Hundred Years War, England fought against which country?
179.note: During the Middle Ages, the English kings also fought a number of wars abroad. Many knights took part in the Crusades, in which European Christians fought for control of the Holy Land. English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War.

180.question: What was the name of the most famous satirical magazine of the 19th century?
180.note: the 19th century, satirical magazines began to be published. The most famous was Punch, which was published for the first time in the 1840s.

181.question: What fraction of the population of England died because of the Black Death?
181.note: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

182.question: In what month of 1945 did the Allies finally defeat Germany?
182.note: Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France and eventually into Germany. The Allies comprehensively defeated Germany in May 1945.

183.question: Which of Shakespeare's plays contains the line 'To be or not to be?'
183.note: Hamlet is the play that contains the line 'to be or not to be'.

184.question: Which British city was almost totally destroyed by German bombing?
184.note: The German air force's night-time bombing of London and other British cities was called the Blitz. Coventry was almost totally destroyed and a great deal of damage was done in other cities, especially in the East End of London.

185.question: Which king defeated the Vikings?
185.note: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

186.question: Who wrote The Canterbury Tales?
186.note: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. 187.question: Who pioneered the railway engine?
187.note: Just before Victoria came to the 47 throne, the father and son George and Robert Stephenson pioneered the railway engine and a major expansion of the railways took place in the Victorian period.

188.question: When Scottish landlords destroyed crofts to make way for large flocks and herds, what was this called?
188.note: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century.

189.question: What nationality was the famous poet and writer Dylan Thomas?
189.note: Dylan Thomas was a Welsh poet and writer. He often read and performed his work in public, including for the BBC.

190.question: Which of these countries was not a founding member of the EU?
190.note: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957.

191.question: Which one of these reforms did the Chartists not campaign for?

options.a: For every man to have a vote
options.d: For every woman to have a vote

191.note: the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote, elections every year, for all regions to be equal in the electoral system, secret ballots, for any man to be able to stand as an MP, for MPs to be paid.

192.question: Which one of these detectives featured in the books of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle?
192.note: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was a Scottish doctor and writer. He was best known for his stories about Sherlock Holmes, who was one of the first fictional detectives.

193.question: In what period was Skara Brae built?
193.note: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

194.question: What is the name of the Paralympian who has won the London Marathon six times and holds 16 Paralympic medals?
194.note: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson (1969-) is an athlete who uses a wheelchair and won 16 Paralympic medals, including 11 gold medals, in races over five Paralympic Games. She won the London Marathon six times and broke a total of 30 world records.

195.question: The first Jews came to Britain in 1656. Where did they settle?
195.note: The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.

196.question: Many of the members of Charles I's Parliament belonged to a Christian group who advocated a strict and simple religious doctrine. What were they called?
196.note: Many in Parliament were Puritans, a group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship.

197.question: Who became Prime Minister of Britain in 1940?
197.note: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister.

198.question: Which one of these countries was invaded by Iraq in 1990 and liberated by coalition forces led by Britain?
198.note: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the Former Republic of Yugoslavia.

199.question: Who was Robert Burns?
199.note: Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English.

200.question: What was Pearl Harbour?
200.note: The United States entered the second World War when the Japanese bombed its naval base at Pearl Harbour in December 1941.

201.question: What character did Charlie Chaplin play in his famous silent movies?
201.note: Sir Charles (Charlie) Chaplin became famous in silent movies for his tramp character and was one of many British actors to make a career in Hollywood.

202.question: What was 'the Norman Conquest'?

options.a: The battle in which the Vikings were defeated
options.b: An invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy
options.d: The area where the Normans settled

202.note: Led by William, the Duke of Normandy, the Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

203.question: On how many occasions has the UK hosted the Olympic Games?
203.note: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012.

204.question: In what year were the Welsh Assembly and Scottish Parliament established?
204.note: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999.

205.question: Tony Blair became Prime Minister in what year?
205.note: In 1997 the Labour Party led by Tony Blair was elected.

206.question: How many Indians fought on behalf of Britain in the First World War?
206.note: The whole of the British Empire was involved in the conflict - for example, more than a million Indians fought on behalf of Britain in lots of different countries, and around 40,000 were killed. 207.question: In what decade did the 'pop art' movement emerge?
207.note: David Hockney was an important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s and continues to be influential today.

208.question: In what year did the English football team win the World Cup?
208.note: England's only international tournament victory was at the World Cup of 1966, hosted in the UK.

209.question: In what year did the world enter the 'Great Depression'?
209.note: In 1929, the world entered the 'Great Depression' and some parts of the UK suffered mass unemployment.

210.question: When was the National Trust founded?
210.note: The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

211.question: In what year was the Norman Conquest?
211.note: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy, defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England.

212.question: How many colonies in America declared independence from Britain in 1776?
212.note: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, 43 stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.

213.question: How many times did Sir Jackie Stewart win the Formula 1 World Championship?
213.note: Sir Jackie Stewart (1939-) is a Scottish former racing driver who won the Formula 1 world championship three times.

214.question: Which one of these painters was not a Pre-Raphaelite artist?
214.note: The Pre-Raphaelites were an important group of artists in the second half of the 19th century. They painted detailed pictures on religious or literary themes in bright colours. The group included Holman Hunt, Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Sir John Millais.

215.question: The conflict between those who wanted full Irish independence and those who were loyal to the British government is often called what?
215.note: The conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the British government is often referred to as 'the Troubles'.

216.question: The 1960s was a period of social change. What name is sometimes given to the 1960s?

217.question: What was the name of the movement against the Pope's authority and the practices of the Roman Church, which swept across Europe?
217.note: At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church. 218.question: What was the main reason why Henry VIII established the Church of England?

options.a: The Pope would not grant him a divorce from Catherine of Aragon
options.b: The Pope would not grant him a divorce from Catherine Howard
options.c: He wanted to have control over the religious life of his country
options.d: He had been converted to Protestantism

219.question: What prompted the United States to enter the war and fight alongside the Allies?

options.a: The Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbour
options.d: The Japanese bombing of New York

220.question: Which famous British company was setup to trade in India but eventually gained control of large areas?

222.question: In which battle did the Duke of Wellington defeat Napoleon?

223.question: What industry was Richard Arkwright involved in?

224.question: Where did the first British farmers come from?
224.note: The first farmers arrived in Britain 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

225.question: Which one of these statements about Florence Nightingale is false?

options.a: She treated soldiers in the Crimean War
options.b: She established the Nightingale Training School
options.d: She trained as a nurse in Italy

226.question: Sir Roger Bannister was the first man to do what?

options.a: Run a mile under four minutes
options.d: Win gold medals in five consecutive Olympics

227.question: Who is known as 'The Bard' in Scotland?

228.question: The name of the leader of the Roundheads was:
228.note: Oliver Cromwell was the leader of the English republic (leader of the Roundheads).

229.question: Which one of these ideas was not established by the Magna Carta?

options.d: The King needed to involve his noblemen in decisions

230.question: In 55 BC, Britain was invaded by the Romans led by who?

231.question: Who wrote The Lord of the Rings?

232.question: Which Prime Minister helped to establish the Northern Ireland peace process?

233.question: Which one of these monarchs was not a child of Henry VIII?

235.question: Which king took the title 'King Of Ireland?'

236.question: For what is Roald Dahl well-known?

options.c: He helped to establish the Northern Ireland peace process
options.d: He was an important member of Margaret Thatcher's government

237.question: What nationality was Queen Anne's successor, George I?

238.question: For whom did George Handel write The Water Music?

239.question: Which of these was not a wife of Henry VIII?

240.question: Which coast of America was colonised by English settlers during Elizabeth I's reign?

241.question: In 2012, the Queen celebrated which jubilee?

244.question: By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale. Where was this located?

245.question: Which country invaded the Falkland Islands, a British territory, in 1982?

246.question: Who was in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar?

247.question: What was a 'round barrow'?

248.question: James I and Charles I both believed in the 'Divine Right of Kings'. What did this mean?

options.a: A King is above the law
options.b: A King is appointed by God to rule
options.d: A King should choose the religion of his people

249.question: In 1348 Britain began to suffer the Black Death. What was the Black Death?

options.a: A disease that affected animal herds
options.d: A disease that affected the crops

250.question: How many British casualties were there on the first day of the Battle of the Somme in 1916?

251.question: In which century did the medieval gothic style of architecture become popular again?

252.question: When did Elizabeth II take the throne?
252.note: The Queen has reigned since her father's death in 1952, and in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as queen).

253.question: In what year did Adolf Hitler come to power in Germany?
253.note: Adolf Hitler came to power in Germany in 1933. He believed that the conditions imposed on Germany by the Allies after the First World War were unfair; he also wanted to conquer more land for the German people.

499.question: One of Britain's shared values and responsibilities is to vote in local and government elections
499.note: Although Britain is one of the world's most diverse societies, there is a set of shared values and responsibilities that everyone can agree with. These values and responsibilities include to vote in local and national government elections.

500.question: Parliamentary proceedings are broadcast on television.
500.note: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be found in large libraries.

501.question: In England, parents and community groups can apply to open a free school in their local area.
501.note: In England, parents and other community groups can apply to open a free school in their local area. More information about this can be found on the Department for Education website.

502.question: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman's husband, can be charged with rape.
502.note: In the UK, brutality and violence in the home is a serious crime. Anyone who is violent towards their partner - whether they are a man or a woman, married or living together - can be prosecuted. Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman's husband, can be charged with rape.

503.question: NATO members have agreed to help each other if they come under attack, and NATO aims to maintain peace between its members.
503.note: NATO is a group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack. It also aims to maintain peace between all of its members.

504.question: A Youth Court is usually presided over by three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge.
504.note: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in a Youth Court in front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge.

505.question: Each MP represents a parliamentary constituency.
505.note: The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election.

506.question: A non-UK national living in the UK and looking for work will need a National Insurance Number
506.note: non-UK national living in the UK and looking for work, starting work or setting up as self-employed will need a National Insurance number. However, you can start work without one.

507.question: Everyone has the legal right to choose their religion.
507.note: Everyone has the legal right to choose their religion, or to choose not to practise a religion.

508.question: Members of the public are allowed in Youth Courts.
508.note: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

509.question: The British constitution is written down in a single document.
509.note: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.

510.question: Civil servants must belong to a political party.
510.note: Civil servants DO NOT have to belong to a political party.

511.question: By 1928 the voting franchise had been extended to include:
511.note: The voting franchise was extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

512.question: Who chairs and represents the Assembly of the Church of Scotland?
512.note: The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

513.question: The second-largest party in the House of Commons are called
513.note: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition. The leader of the opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

514.question: MPs from the second-largest party form their own cabinet. What is it called?
514.note: The leader of the opposition also appoints senior opposition MPs to be 'shadow ministers'. They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

515.question: As the legal system became established, judges to England agreed to set law based
515.note: In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition.

516.question: Which of these departments would you need to contact for a National Insurance Number?
516.note: If you have permission to work in the UK, you will need to telephone the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to arrange to get a National Insurance number.

517.question: What is the name of the system by which employers take income tax from their employees' earnings?
517.note: For most people, the right amount of income tax is automatically taken from their income from employment by their employer and paid directly to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), the government department that collects taxes. This system is called 'Pay As You Earn' (PAYE).

518.question: Who is the head of state?
518.note: Queen Elizabeth II is the head of state of the UK. She is also the monarch or head of state for many countries in the Commonwealth.

519.question: All of the elected MPs form:
519.note: The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons.

520.question: MOT stands for:
520.note: MOT stands for the Ministry of Transport.

521.question: Which one of these statements about TV licences is false?

options.a: You must have a licence for each piece of equipment that can be used to watch TV
options.b: Tenants must have their own TV licence
options.c: If you are over 75, you can apply for a free TV licence
options.d: Blind people can get a 50% discount on their TV licence

521.note: One licence covers all of the equipment in one home, except when people rent different rooms in a shared house and each has a separate tenancy agreement - those people must each buy a separate licence.

522.question: What are solicitors' charges based on?

options.a: How much time they spend on a case
options.b: How much money they spend on a case
options.d: How much money they make from a case

522.note: Solicitors' charges are usually based on how much 147 time they spend on a case. It is very important to find out at the start how much a case is likely to cost.

523.question: What is the Home Secretary responsible for?
523.note: Home Secretary is responsible for crime, policing and immigration.

524.question: In 1847, the law limited the number of hours women and children could work. How many hours could they work per day?
524.note: In 1847, the number of hours that women and children could work was limited by law to 10 hours per day.

525.question: How old must you be to stand for election as an MP?
525.note: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties.

526.question: When was the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act brought into effect?
526.note: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

527.question: Which type of court is not found in England?
527.note: In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a Sheriff Court with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury.

528.question: In which one of these countries are minor criminal offences dealt with in a Justice of the Peace Court rather than the Magistrates' Court?
528.note: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

529.question: What is the Chancellor of the Exchequer responsible for?
529.note: The Chancellor of the Exchequer is responsible for the economy.

530.question: Which of these is not a major political party?
530.note: The Democratic Alliance is not a major political party.

531.question: Who chairs debates in the House of Commons?
531.note: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker. This person is the chief officer of the House of Commons.

532.question: The Education Act of 1944 is often called what?
532.note: Richard Austen Butler became a Conservative MP in 1923 and held several positions before becoming responsible for education in 1941. In this role, he oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called 'The Butler Act'), which introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.

533.question: Which one of these tasks is not the duty of a Police and Crime Commissioner?
533.note: In November 2012, the public elected Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) in England and Wales. These are directly elected individuals who are responsible for the delivery of an efficient and effective police force that reflects the needs of their local communities. PCCs set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the local Chief Constable.

534.question: What are members of the Scottish Parliament called?
534.note: There are 129 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), elected by a form of proportional representation.

535.question: Which one of these statements about legal rights is false?

options.a: Men and women have equal rights to work
options.b: A married couple are equally responsible for their children
options.c: Men and women have equal rights to divorce
options.d: Women can only buy property if over 30

535.note: Within the UK, it is a legal requirement that men and women should not be discriminated against because of their gender or because they are, or are not, married. They have equal rights to work, own property, marry and divorce. If they are married, both parents are equally responsible for their children.

536.question: Prime Minister's Questions' take place how often when parliament is sitting?
536.note: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government's failures and weaknesses. One important opportunity to do this is at Prime Minister's Questions, which takes place every week while Parliament is sitting.

537.question: What are members of the European Parliament called?
537.note: Elections for the European Parliament are also held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs).

538.question: In which country are there three verdicts possible at a trial?
538.note: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of 'not proven' is also possible.

539.question: When do young people receive their National Insurance Number?
539.note: A National Insurance number is a unique personal account number. It makes sure that the National Insurance Contributions and tax you pay are properly recorded against your name. All young people in the UK are sent a National Insurance number just before their 16th birthday.

540.question: What is the National Citizen Service programme?

options.a: An accredited compulsory programme of community work for 16 to 17 year olds
options.b: An accredited programme for people of all ages taking part in a community project
options.c: An accredited compulsory programme of community work for new British Citizens
options.d: An accredited programme for 16 and 17 year olds taking part in a community project

540.note: There are many opportunities for younger people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

541.question: What is a solicitor?

options.a: A police officer who attends court
options.c: A legal adviser who works for the Citizens Advice Bureau
options.d: A judge who presides over a small claims court

541.note: Solicitors are trained lawyers who give advice on legal matters, take action for their clients and represent their clients in court.

542.question: Which one of these facts about UK driving licences is false?

options.a: To get a driving licence, you must pass a test
options.b: A driving test will test only your driving knowledge
options.c: A driving test will test your knowledge and your driving skills
options.d: A driving licence is needed to drive on any public roads

542.note: To get a UK driving licence you must pass a driving test, which tests both your knowledge and your practical skills. You need to be at least 16 years old to ride a moped, and there are other age requirements and special tests for driving large vehicles.

543.question: How old must you be to drive a car?
543.note: In the UK, you must be at least 17 years old to drive a car or motor cycle and you must have a driving licence to drive on public roads.

544.question: How old must you be to drink wine or beer with a meal in a restaurant?
544.note: To buy alcohol in a pub or night club you must be 18 or over, but people under that age may be allowed in some pubs with an adult. When they are 16, people can drink wine or beer with a meal in a hotel or restaurant (including eating areas in pubs) as long as they are with someone over 18.

545.question: In which year was the voting age reduced to 18 for men and women?
545.note: In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

546.question: Which one of these facts about Magistrates and Justices of the Peace in England, Scotland and Wales is false?

options.c: They are members of the local community
options.d: They do not need legal qualification

546.note: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the local community. In England, Wales and Scotland they usually work 144 unpaid and do not need legal qualifications.

547.question: Who appoints members of the Cabinet?
547.note: The Prime Minister (PM) is the leader of the political party in power. He or she appoints the members of the cabinet and has control over many important public appointments.

548.question: What title is given to the person who is the ceremonial leader of a local council?
548.note: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council.

549.question: A similar Parliament developed in Scotland, with three Houses or Estates. Which one of these was not an Estate?
549.note: In England, parliaments were called for the king to consult his nobles, particularly when the king needed to raise money. A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.

550.question: What was the EU originally called?
550.note: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957.

551.question: What are members of the House of Lords known as?
551.note: Members of the House of Lords, known as peers, are not elected by the people and do not represent a constituency.

552.question: What does NATO stand for?
552.note: The UK developed its own atomic bomb and joined the new North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), an alliance of nations set up to resist the perceived threat of invasion by the Soviet Union and its allies.

553.question: In which parts of Parliament are the public allowed to listen to debates?

options.a: In both the House of Commons and the House of Lords
options.b: Only in the House of Commons
options.c: Only in the House of Lords

553.note: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

554.question: Where is a small claims procedure held?

options.a: In an ordinary room in front of a judge
options.d: In an ordinary room in front of a solicitor

554.note: The hearing is held in front of a judge in an ordinary room, and people from both sides of the dispute sit around a table.

555.question: Which one of these statements about the reign of Charles I is false?

options.a: He inherited the thrones of England, Wales, Ireland and Scotland
options.b: He sought Parliament's approval for all his decisions
options.c: He believed he should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament
options.d: For 11 years he found ways to raise money without Parliament's approval

555.note: James I and his son Charles I both believed in the 'Divine Right of Kings': the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. They thought that the king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

556.question: Which one of these statements about visiting Parliament is false?

options.a: You can queue at the door on the day
options.c: You can ask your MP in advance for tickets

556.note: You can write to your local MP in advance to ask for tickets or you can queue on the day at the public entrance. Entrance is free. Sometimes there are long queues for the House of Commons and people have to wait for at least one or two hours.

557.question: Which one of these concerns criminal law, not civil law?
557.note: Criminal law relates to crimes, which are usually investigated by the police or another authority such as a council, and which are punished by the courts. Civil law is used to settle disputes between individuals or groups. Drinking in public concerns criminal law.

558.question: Where in the Senedd does the National Assembly for Wales meets?
558.note: In Wales the elected members, known as AMs, meet in the Welsh Assembly in the Senedd in Cardiff Bay.

559.question: How often is a general election held?
559.note: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

560.question: Which of these is not defined as a forced marriage?

options.a: A marriage where both partners do not agree
options.b: An arranged marriage where both partners consent
options.c: A marriage where one partner does not agree
options.d: A marriage where either partner cannot give consent

560.note: A marriage should be entered into with the full and free consent of both people involved. Arranged marriages, where both parties agree to the marriage, are acceptable in the UK. Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership.

561.question: Which of these citizens would not be allowed to stand for office as an MP?

options.b: A citizen of another EU country

561.note: British citizens can stand for office as a local councillor, a member of Parliament (or the devolved equivalents) or a member of the European Parliament. You may also be able to stand for office if you are an Irish citizen, an eligible Commonwealth citizen or (except for standing to be an MP) a citizen of another EU country.

562.question: Which one of these is not a voluntary role?
562.note: The police are organised into a number of separate police forces headed by Chief Constables. They are independent of the government. Chief Constables are not voluntary.

563.question: To what age can a person use their driving licence?
563.note: Drivers can use their driving licence until they are 70 years old. After that, the licence is valid for three years at a time.

564.question: How old must your vehicle be before you are required to have an MOT certificate for it?
564.note: It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

565.question: In what year was the Northern Ireland Assembly established?
565.note: The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement (or Good Friday Agreement) in 1998. There is a power-sharing agreement which distributes ministerial offices amongst the main parties.

566.question: How old must you be to buy alcohol in a night club or pub?
566.note: To buy alcohol in a pub or night club you must be 18 or over, but people under that age may be allowed in some pubs with an adult.

567.question: How old must you be to go into a betting shop or gambling club?
567.note: You have to be 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

568.question: How old must you be to drive a moped?
568.note: You need to be at least 16 years old to ride a moped, and there are other age requirements and special tests for driving large vehicles.

569.question: How many people are on a jury in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
569.note: A jury is made up of members of the public chosen at random from the local electoral register. In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

570.question: Which fact about the Prime Minister is false?

options.a: They have two official residences in London
options.b: They usually resign if their party loses a General Election
options.c: They can be changed if the MPs of their party decide to do so
options.d: They are the leader of the political party in power

570.note: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament.

571.question: Who chooses the Speaker?

options.b: The House of Lords, via a secret ballot

571.note: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP. The Speaker is chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot.

572.question: what is the term for MPs who do not represent a political party?
572.note: There are a few MPs who do not represent any of the main political parties. They are called 'independents' and usually represent an issue important to their constituency.

573.question: The head of a local police force is called:
573.note: The police are organised into a number of separate police forces headed by Chief Constables. They are independent of the government.

574.question: Which one of these concerns civil law, not criminal law?
574.note: Criminal law relates to crimes, which are usually investigated by the police or another authority such as a council, and which are punished by the courts. Civil law is used to settle disputes between individuals or groups. Consumer rights concerns the civil law.

575.question: Which one of these is not a legal requirement if you own and drive a vehicle?
575.note: If you are resident in the UK, your car or motor cycle must be registered at the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA). You must pay an annual road tax and display the tax disc, which shows that the tax has been paid, on the windscreen. You must also have valid motor insurance.

576.question: The system through which MPs are elected is called:
576.note: MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected.

577.question: Which one of these statements about banknotes is false?

options.b: Shops and businesses have to accept Scotland's banknotes
options.c: Northern Ireland banknotes are valid everywhere in the UK
options.d: British Pound banknotes are valid everywhere in the UK

577.note: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

578.question: County Courts deal with what kind of cases?
578.note: County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes. These include people trying to get back money that is owed to them, cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract, and divorce.

579.question: Which of these facts about the House of Lords in false?

options.b: Hereditary peers have an automatic right to attend the House of Lords
options.c: It can overrule the House of Commons
options.d: It checks laws passed by the House of Commons

579.note: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

580.question: What did the Education Act of 1944 introduce?
580.note: The Education Act 1944 (often called 'The Butler Act') introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.

581.question: How often are elections for the European Parliament held?
581.note: Elections for the European Parliament are held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs).

582.question: Where does the Scottish Parliament sit?
582.note: The Scottish Parliament was formed in 1999. It sits in Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland.

583.question: Which one of these statements is false?

options.a: The government is chosen in a democratic election
options.b: In the UK, the monarch does not rule, but appoints a government
options.c: The monarch invites the political party they favour to form a government
options.d: Decisions of government policies are made by the Prime Minister and Cabinet

583.note: All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government.

584.question: What were 'pocket boroughs'?

options.b: Constituencies where people were paid to vote
options.c: Constituencies controlled by a single wealthy family

584.note: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution are the beginning of what is called 'constitutional monarchy'. Only men who owned property of a certain value were able to vote. No women at all had the vote. Some constituencies were controlled by a single wealthy family. These were called 'pocket boroughs'.

585.question: A Youth Court or in Scotland, a Children's Hearing, is held for less serious cases when a child is how old?
585.note: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in a Youth Court in front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge.

586.question: Which groups of UK residents cannot vote in General Elections?

options.b: Adult citizens of the Irish Republic
options.c: Adult citizens of other EU states

586.note: Adult citizens of other EU states who are resident in the UK can vote in all elections except General Elections.

587.question: How many senior MPs form the cabinet?
587.note: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments.

588.question: What must be worn by all dogs in public places?

options.c: A collar that shows the name and address of the owner

588.note: All dogs in public places must wear a collar showing the name and address of the owner. The owner is responsible for keeping the dog under control and for cleaning up after the animal in a public place.

589.question: Between what hours are elections open?
589.note: On election day, the polling station or place will be open from 7.00 am until 10.00 pm.

590.question: In Northern Ireland, how long must a newly qualified driver display an 'R' plate?
590.note: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an 'R' plate (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

591.question: How many members does the Welsh Assembly have?
591.note: The Welsh government and National Assembly for Wales are based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales. The National Assembly has 60 Assembly members (AMs) and elections are held every four years 129 using a form of proportional representation.

592.question: If you have a driving licence that is not valid in the UK, how long can you use it before you must get a full UK licence?
592.note: If your driving licence is from a country in the European Union (EU), Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway, you can drive in the UK for as long as your licence is valid. If you have a licence from any other country, you may use it in the UK for up to 12 months. To continue driving after that, you must get a UK full driving licence.

593.question: When were Police and Crime Commissioners elected?
593.note: In November 2012, the public elected Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) in England and Wales. These are directly elected individuals who are responsible for the delivery of an efficient and effective police force that reflects the needs of their local communities.

594.question: How many years can someone be jailed for breaching a Forced Marriage Protection Order?
594.note: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.  A potential victim, or someone acting for them, can apply for an order. Anyone found to have breached an order can be jailed for up to two years for contempt of court.

595.question: How many members are there on a Scottish jury?
595.note: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

596.question: A right to a fair trial is not offered by the UK to citizens and permanent residents
596.note: Some of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights are: right to life, prohibition of torture, prohibition of slavery and forced labour, right to liberty and security, right to a fair trial, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom to expression (speech)

597.question: Freedom of speech is not offered by the UK to citizens and permanent residents
597.note: Some of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights are: right to life, prohibition of torture, prohibition of slavery and forced labour, right to liberty and security, right to a fair trial, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom to expression (speech)

598.question: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs is a fundamental principle of British life
598.note: Some of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights are: right to life, prohibition of torture, prohibition of slavery and forced labour, right to liberty and security, right to a fair trial, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom to expression (speech)

599.question: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of British Life
599.note: Some of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights are: right to life, prohibition of torture, prohibition of slavery and forced labour, right to liberty and security, right to a fair trial, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom to expression (speech)

600.question: Which one of the following is false about shopping locally?

options.a: Shopping locally helps businesses and farmers in your area
options.b: Shopping locally reduces your carbon footprint
options.d: Shopping locally helps the local economy

600.note: A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

601.question: In many families today, both partners work and share responsibility for childcare.
601.note: It is no longer expected that women should stay at home and not work. Women often continue to work after having children. In many families today, both partners work and both share responsibility for childcare and household chores.

602.question: There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.
602.note: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

603.question: Ramadan is a period of fasting for Sikhs.
603.note: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast.

604.question: On Sundays and public holidays:

options.c: Trading hours are usually the same as normal

604.note: Most shops in the UK are open seven days a week, although trading hours on Sundays and public holidays are generally reduced.

605.question: Which one of these is not one of Britain's 'shared values and responsibilities'?

options.a: To respect and preserve the environment
options.b: To only eat food produced in Britain
options.c: To obey and respect the law

605.note: Although Britain is one of the world's most diverse societies, there is a set of shared values and responsibilities that everyone can agree with. These values and responsibilities DO NOT include to only eat food produced in Britain.

606.question: Who is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth?
606.note: The Queen is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 54 member states.

607.question: What does Christmas celebrate?

options.a: The birth of John the Baptist
options.d: The death of John The Baptist

607.note: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday.

608.question: By what name is Diwali often called?
608.note: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights.

609.question: The end of Ramadan is marked by which festival?
609.note: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month.

610.question: In which sport do teams from Oxford and Cambridge Universities compete in an annual race at the River Thames?
610.note: Rowing is popular, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport. There is a popular yearly race on the Thames between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

611.question: What is the official Church of the state?

options.c: There is no official Church of the state

611.note: The official Church of the state is the Church of England (called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States).

612.question: Which area of London is known as 'Theatreland' because of its cluster of famous theatres?
612.note: There are theatres in most towns and cities throughout the UK, 92 ranging from the large to the small. They are an important part of local communities and often show both professional and amateur productions. London's West End, also known as 'Theatreland', is particularly well known.

613.question: Diwali is celebrated by what two religions?
613.note: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs.

614.question: When is the song Auld Lang Syne traditionally sung in many countries?
